Peter, how to represent the geometry of a rag doll in the substrate is
an o=
pen question right now with a lot of possible answers.  The
easiest part of=
 the answer is probably just that the inputs and
outputs should be in a con=
figuration that is projected from the shape
of the body, and both inputs an=
d outputs should have correlated geometry.

However, the little questions a=
re the hard ones, like what to do when
there are multiple degrees of freedo=
m at the same location (such as a
hip).  It seems erroneous to simply squee=
ze such different directions
arbitrarily into the same area. Perhaps more u=
seful would be to have
multiple input and output layers, each with a map of=
 the joints of the
body that rotate along a certain axis.

The multiple lay=
ers could be joined together on a 3rd dimension, or
effectively completely =
separated by making them separate inputs or
outputs (i.e. by having multipl=
e sets of inputs or outputs).  

To simplify the problem, you might start o=
ut for practice with a robot
that only has a single degree of freedom at ea=
ch joint.  That way, you
could just have a single input map and a single ou=
tput map without any
difficult conceptual issues.  If it works out well, yo=
u could expand
from there to more complex representations.

Like I said, th=
is research area is an experiment in progress, but I do
believe we will eve=
ntually have some standard practices for how to
project a body onto a subst=
rate.  I'd be interested in hearing
anything you find out.

ken
